Notable novels by Ugandan women writers:  Jennifer Makumbi's 'Kintu' (2014) wove together centuries of Ugandan history through multiple generations of one family.  Information not found

Notable works by Ugandan authors include:  Moses' series of children's books by Barbara Kimenye  - 'Moses' (1968) - 'Moses and Mildred' - 'Moses in Trouble' - 'Moses and the School Farm'  Okot p'Bitek's works: - 'Song of Lawino' (1966) - 'Song of Ocol' (1970) - 'Song of a Prisoner' (1971) - 'Song of Malaya' (1971) - 'White Teeth' (novel)  Other notable works: - 'Abyssinian Chronicles' by Moses Isegawa (1998) - 'Kintu' by Jennifer Makumbi (2014)

Binyavanga Wainaina's notable literary works include:   'How to Write About Africa' (2005) - a satirical essay   'One Day I Will Write About This Place' (2011) - a memoir   'Discovering Home' (2002) - a story that won the Caine Prize for African Writing

Meja Mwangi's novels critiquing neocolonialism and corruption include:  Mwafaka Passbook Going Down River Road Till the Lion Comes
Ngugi wa Thiong'o shifted to writing in his native Gikuyu language.   During his detention in 1977, he wrote 'Devil on the Cross' on toilet paper, marking his first novel in the Gikuyu language.
Notable autobiographical works by Yolande Mukagasana include:  La Mort ne veut pas de moi (Death Does Not Want Me, 1997)  N'aie pas peur de savoir (Don't Be Afraid to Know, 1999)

Notable works by Okot p'Bitek include:  Song of Lawino (1966) Song of Ocol (1970) Song of a Prisoner (1971) Song of Malaya (1971) White Teeth (novel, no specific year mentioned)  These works showcase p'Bitek's exploration of cultural clashes, traditional values, and Western modernization, as well as his scholarly interests in African religions and oral literature.
